sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1:
In a 3-dimensional Euclidean space, suppose we have a metric given by
$$
ds^2 = 4(dx_1)^2 + 9(dx_2)^2 + 16(dx_3)^2.
$$
Find the volume form associated to this metric at point $(1,2,3)$.
message_2:
To find the volume form associated with the given metric, we first need to find the determinant of the metric tensor. The metric tensor for the given metric is a diagonal matrix with the coefficients of the differentials:

$$
g = \begin{pmatrix}
4 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 9 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 16
\end{pmatrix}
$$

The determinant of this diagonal matrix is simply the product of its diagonal elements:

$$
\det(g) = 4 \cdot 9 \cdot 16 = 576
$$

Now, the volume form is given by the square root of the determinant of the metric tensor times the standard volume form in Euclidean space, which is $dx_1 \wedge dx_2 \wedge dx_3$:

$$
\text{vol} = \sqrt{\det(g)} \, dx_1 \wedge dx_2 \wedge dx_3 = \sqrt{576} \, dx_1 \wedge dx_2 \wedge dx_3
$$

So, the volume form associated with the given metric at point $(1,2,3)$ is:

$$
\text{vol} = 24 \, dx_1 \wedge dx_2 \wedge dx_3
$$
